entry.title: Speeding up your SAP HCM move to the cloud in 2024
entry.content:
Speeding up your SAP HCM move to the cloud in 2024

2023 was another record-setting year for SAP customers moving their Human Capital Management processes to the cloud.  More SAP ERP HCM customers than ever before embarked on the journey with us, from hire-to-retire, including core HR, time, payroll and much more.

New tools, services and assets are helping to accelerate and de-risk the process of moving HR to the cloud. Several are even free, or available at no extra cost to customers with SAP Support. This blog post will be the first of three in a series covering developments that may be new to many of you, specifically:

Part 1:   SAP Readiness Check for SAP SuccessFactors Solutions

Part 2:   SAP Customer Evolution Kit for HXM (Human Experience Management)

Part 3:   Enterprise Strategy Group Economic Value study for moving from SAP ERP HCM to SAP SuccessFactors

 

SAP Readiness Check for SAP SuccessFactors solutions

From its launch in October 2022, SAP Readiness Check for SAP SuccessFactors solutions tool adoption has outpaced our most optimistic projections. Feedback from customers and partners has been universally enthusiastic, and they are telling their friends – and us. And that input has led us to make the tool even better through more than a dozen enhancements delivered in 2023, with more to come in 2024.

SAP Readiness Check for SAP SuccessFactors solutions tool has now been run more than 500 times, in 42 countries, helping customers to accelerate and de-risk their moves beyond on-premise SAP ERP Human Capital Management.

This SAP Readiness Check tool has saved many of these customers big money on consulting costs, while providing the equivalent of an MRI or x-ray into their as-deployed HCM configuration, including integrations, customizations, and usage data for key processes. Many customers have run it several times, in order to confirm the effect of their pre-migration clean-up efforts. Customers with employee counts ranging from under 500 employees to those with over 500,000 have all accrued benefits.

Based on the analysis of the source system, the tool provides a comprehensive overview of specific parameters delivering:

Employee Insights

This reveals the distribution of employee master data figures per region, process, or status. Leverage this information in further discussions with an implementation partner to assess the migration project complexity.

Organizational Structure Analysis

Insight into the organizational structure master data will help to establish an understanding of key figures related to the allocation of employee-related data.

Important HCM Data

Insight into other HCM objects relevant to the HCM system setup, such as payroll calendars and payroll frequency defined within the analyzed system.

Custom Code Analysis

Insight into the volume and variety of custom code objects.

Understanding the status quo is a vital starting point for your HR journey to the cloud, which SAP Readiness Check for SAP SuccessFactors solutions tool delivers. The next step typically entails engaging experts to help you to understand your options, and to build your case for change. We’ve got a couple of options to help, specifically:

The SAP Customer Evolution Kit for HXM provides SAP ERP HCM customers with a free workshop to help them get ready to modernize their HR system. The engagement provides customers with expert help for building a value case, interpreting their SAP Readiness Check results and mapping solutions to support their modernization. 

Alternately, for customers just wanting to engage a specialist to review their SAP Readiness Check results, the Customer Success Services team from SAP offers Advisory Service for SAP Readiness Check for SAP SuccessFactors solutions, available for a modest fee via the SAP Store.

More details about the SAP Customer Evolution Kit for HXM will follow in Part 2, and in Part 3 of this blog series, we will look at how customers can deliver ROI (return on investment) of 100% or more from their HCM evolution projects.

Please also mark your calendar and click to register for an upcoming webinar on May 16th titled "Fast-track your HR journey to the cloud with SAP partners"

entry.title: Speeding up your SAP HCM move to the cloud in 2024 - Part 2: Customer Evolution Kit for HCM
entry.content:
What is the SAP Customer Evolution Kit for HCM?

The SAP Customer Evolution kit for HCM is a cost-free, quick, and efficient engagement that provides a clear and seamless path for businesses and the partners who support them to accelerate transition from their on-premise SAP HCM solution to SAP SuccessFactors. It is delivered virtually by real live SAP experts, featuring a set of tools, methodologies, and services designed to simplify and streamline the migration process, while minimizing risks and ensuring business continuity.

This SAP Customer Evolution kit helps customers address the challenges associated with migrating critical HCM data, configurations, and integrations from their on-premises systems to the cloud. With its step-by-step guidance, customers can plan, execute, and validate their migration strategies, ensuring a smooth and successful transition to SAP SuccessFactors.

In Part 1 of this blog series, I shared some of the features and benefits of the SAP Readiness Check for SAP SuccessFactors solutions. While SAP Readiness Checks can be run on a self-service basis, they are a bit like medical MRIs or X-rays in that, even if you could snap the picture yourself, the images are best interpreted by an expert trained in how to interpret the findings and recommend treatment plans. The SAP Customer Evolution kit for HCM provides you with the business equivalent of a radiologist, to provide expert readout of your organization’s unique SAP Readiness Check results, along with recommendations based on the findings.

Accelerating migrations for customers facing the end of maintenance or compatibility pack rights

For businesses currently running on SAP HCM on-premises solutions, the clock is ticking. SAP has announced that mainstream maintenance for older enhancement packs of the on-premises HCM solution ends at the end of 2025. Many SAP S/4HANA customers running HCM and Finance together in the same environment also face expiration of compatibility pack rights at the end of 2025. This means that customers need to act now to ensure they are ready for the future while maintaining compliance and performance, as well as tapping innovations like Joule to bring relevant, reliable, responsible AI to HCM and the broader enterprise.

The SAP Customer Evolution kit for HCM offers a unique opportunity for these customers to accelerate their migration journey. Over the course of three half-day sessions, and at no charge, it provides a roadmap and best practices to assess existing landscapes, identify gaps, and define a customized migration plan that aligns with unique goals and requirements.

During these SAP Customer Evolution kit engagements, we’ve seen customers make all sorts of realizations about their legacy systems. These often include “Aha!” moments, when they realize that their current highly customized processes could be moved back to standard, easily supported standard functionality within SAP SuccessFactors HCM. Examples of such “Aha!” topics include:

  • Legacy customizations supporting Concurrent Employment that required multiple PERNRs in on-prem could be more readily supported using standard configuration capabilities in Employee Central
  • Grade step progression logic to support collective bargaining agreements that required custom infotypes in HCM could be supported using standard SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central and Compensation functionality
  • Support for Higher Duties and Grants and Funds accounting for Public Sector are available in SAP SuccessFactors.

These kinds of insights can rapidly demystify the legacy environment, clarify the state of the possible and provide expert guidance on how best to move forward to the cloud with the utmost confidence that all required business processes will be supported.

So, if you’re looking for a free, fast, and helpful way to get organized around your HCM move to the cloud, we have the workshop to get you going.

Lead times to engage our experts are stretching as 2025 deadlines approach. Please sign up for your free SAP Customer Evolution Kit for HCM today!

Please also mark your calendar and click to register for an upcoming webinar on May 16th titled "Fast-track your HR journey to the cloud with SAP partners"

entry.title: Enhanced Initial Data Migration Profile in SAP Readiness Check for SAP ERP Usage and Data Profiling
entry.content:
We are happy to announce the enhancement of the “Initial Data Migration Profile” in SAP Readiness Check for SAP ERP Usage and Data Profiling.

Figure 1: The old and new view of the Initial Data Migration Profile

The Initial Data Migration Profile of the SAP Readiness Check for SAP ERP Usage and Data Profiling analyzes important SAP ERP 6.0 data objects and their data volumes. The profile data delivers valuable input for the often tedious and costly exercise of manually scoping and assessing data objects. With this newest release, we have enhanced the data collector and revamped the user experience when reviewing the results, displaying more information, and offering additional capabilities for slicing and dicing the information.

The following list highlights the new and enhanced features that are described in more detail further below:

  • Where possible, a deeper level of data analysis providing more insight into the business objects
  • Filtering and grouping functions to enhance the user experience
  • Introduction of new interactive UI elements to assist in the visualization of the findings
  • The ability to run “what-if” scenarios supporting a selective data transition approach
  • Where applicable, insight into the history of the data volume
  • Identification of unused data objects and deprecated organizational units

The New Data Collector

We completely redesigned the Initial Data Profile data collector from scratch, replacing the existing collector as it only provided limited information regarding the analyzed data objects.

The scoping and development of the new data collector was done in cooperation and collaboration with the SAP Business Data Transformation Solutions team. SAP Readiness Check for SAP ERP Usage and Data Profiling and SAP Business Transformation Center now use the same data collector. This alignment helps expedite the move from evaluating and scoping to planning and conducting a selective data transition project.

Business objects are now used as data object identifiers, more commonly used to represent real-world artifacts than database table names. In total, 215 business objects are now analyzed by the data collector.

We have extended the analysis beyond the high-level data volume figures for many business objects and now provide insights into additional valuable data. For instance, you can now group results by organizational elements (e.g., company codes, plants, or sales organizations) depending on the attributes of the business object.

The data volumes can also be categorized in a historical context for business objects containing the necessary date attributes by defining year range filters.

Additionally, the new data collector now determines the first and last recorded activity dates for applicable business objects, helping to identify business objects no longer in use and resulting in a leaner data scope for the data migration.

These added values help project teams decide on the best transition approach. For instance, the Initial Data Migration Profile result can be used to evaluate the feasibility of a selective data transition approach by gaining initial insight into expected data volumes and facilitating the definition of the data scope. If the selective data transition approach is an option for your transition project, you can continue to investigate the data in detail and create a digital blueprint with the tool.

The New Initial Data Migration Profile User Experience

Figure 2: The new Initial Data Migration Profile dashboard card

The Initial Data Migration Profile dashboard card now presents a pie chart instead of a bar chart indicating the top 6 business objects by volume (see Fig. 2). To open the detail view, select any item from the pie chart or the dashboard card header.

The detailed view of the Initial Data Migration Profile was newly created from scratch and follows a flexible column layout model, which is available in many other SAP Fiori apps. The view lets users quickly expand the column they want to focus on and switch between different layouts.

Figure 3: The new Initial Data Migration Profile view in 1-column mode

By default, the view displays a table of all analyzed business objects (fig. 3) including the following columns:

  • business object name
  • application component
  • related table name of the business object
  • data type (master or transactional data)
  • latest activity
  • total number of items

Initially, the table is sorted by the number of items in descending order, which can be changed using the corresponding button on the top right of the table control. The content of the table can also be exported to a spreadsheet.

To quickly search for a specific business object, start typing the object’s name into the search field on top of the table, and the table will filter accordingly.

Business objects with in-depth data analysis available have a detail indicator to the right of the last column in the row. Selecting a business object switches the view to the 2-column (detail) mode. The business object list is now shown in a compressed format on the left, while the detailed data of the selected business object is presented on the right side (see Fig. 4).

To increase the space of the detail column to full screen or to close the detail column, use the corresponding buttons in the top right corner.

Figure 4: 2-column mode of the view showing the details of the selected business object

The right column within the view is divided into two parts. The filter criteria and KPIs of the selected business object are shown at the top. The lower section presents charts and tables to visualize and support analyzing the data based on the selected filter criteria.

The capabilities that can be used to group and filter the business object data depend on the attributes of the selected business object. For example, the “FI Documents” business object has the filter criteria year and company code available. Other business objects, like “Equipment,” do not contain any aspect of time but can be grouped by plant. Some objects do not have any grouping capability, such as the business object “Status Management.” For these business objects, no detailed data is available.

When the business object data contains date attributes, use the range slider control to set different intervals by year. The data is immediately filtered according to the selected range. Use the corresponding multi-select combo boxes to select filter criteria for organizational key elements, like company code or plant. All selected filter criteria are applied to the data immediately using “AND” logic.

The Selected Data Ratio KPI visualizes the ratio between the total data volume of the selected business object and the data volume based on the applied filter conditions. Additionally, the business object’s oldest and latest activity dates are shown in the KPI section. The values for the total and filtered data volumes are displayed to help identify unused or no longer used business objects.

Depending on the capabilities of the business object’s grouping criteria, you can select different options to present and examine the business object volume data using the toolbar at the top of the data section. For example, the data within the “FI Document” business object can be analyzed using the following charts and tables:

Figure 5: Different options to present and examine the business object data

When using the table option to view the business object detail, the table content can be exported to a spreadsheet for further processing by selecting the export button on top of the table.

Filter Criteria Views

To increase usability, the new Initial Data Migration Profile allows users not only to define and activate filter criteria for organizational and date-related key figures (e.g., company code, plants, year of creation, etc.) but to store them persistently in filter criteria views, which – once activated – are applied to all business object data, provided the criteria fields exist in the business object (otherwise the filter criteria is ignored).

This feature supports ongoing discussions about the data migration scope: You can define filter criteria views for different data migration scenarios and use them for what-if analysis. For example, you can save filter criteria evaluating the impact of migrating 3 or 4 years of historical data to the new system or analyze the effects of carving out one or more company codes.

Figure 6: Expand and hide the filter section

To set up a filter criteria view, expand the filter section above the business object table by selecting the related button (see Fig. 6). The filter section includes a set of multi-select combo boxes for all the available filter criteria. Choosing the values in these combo boxes defines the criteria for your filtered view. To apply your view’s filter criteria, select the Go button at the bottom of the filter section (see Fig. 7).

Figure 7: Setting up filter criteria views which are applied to all business objects

If you want to save your filtered view persistently for the analysis, select the drop-down button on top of the filter section (next to the caption “Standard”; see Fig. 7 and 8). This opens the “My Views” pop-up window, which lists any existing filter criteria views of the analysis and offers buttons to either save the currently selected filter criteria into a new view or to manage existing views (see Fig. 8).

Figure 8: Create and manage filter criteria views

To run an SAP Readiness Check for SAP ERP Usage and Data Profiling analysis, follow the instructions described in SAP Note 3112362.

You can also update an existing analysis by implementing the latest version of SAP Note 3112362 and running the analysis in your SAP ERP system again. Then, use the Update Analysis option within the header of the dashboard view within the SAP Readiness Check cloud app to update the analysis data.

As always, we are interested in your feedback!

Your SAP Readiness Check Team

entry.title: Speeding up your SAP HCM move to the cloud in 2024 - Part 3: SAP HCM ROI Calculator
entry.content:
Are you considering making the move from on-prem HCM to SAP SuccessFactors but struggling to quantify the potential return on investment (ROI)? Look no further, because SAP has just the tool for you - the SAP HCM ROI Calculator.

HCM ROI Calculation example

 

This free, user-friendly calculator is based on the study "Analyzing the Economic Benefits of Moving from SAP ERP HCM to SAP SuccessFactors," conducted by Enterprise Strategy Group (ESG). The study found that organizations can realize a typical 107% return on investment when making the switch. The calculator allows users to enter as few as 4 data points to get started, providing a quick and easy way to estimate the potential ROI of moving to SAP SuccessFactors.  You can also access the complete ESG study directly from the same page, as well as sign up for a free HCM Customer Evolution Kit workshop, in which SAP experts can help you to formulate a winning plan for your move to the cloud.

But that's not all - for those who want to dive deeper into the analysis, the calculator offers more than 20 optional additional data points that allow users to fine-tune their model and get a more customized ROI estimation and further explore the potential financial benefits of making the transition to SAP SuccessFactors.

The calculator is available now and is a valuable tool for organizations looking to make an informed decision about their HCM system. Whether you're in the early stages of considering a move or are ready to take the next steps, the SAP HCM ROI Calculator can provide you with the insights you need to make a well-informed decision.

We also recognize that for some customers, the SAP HCM ROI Calculator will be more of a conversation starter, or a source of input for a more extensive business case.  If this is your situation, then our SAP Value Advisors can help.  Should this be of interest, please contact your SAP account representative to get started.

In addition to the potential financial benefits, SAP SuccessFactors offers a range of features and capabilities that can help businesses keep up with the evolving demands of the modern workforce. From talent management and employee engagement tools to analytics and reporting capabilities, SAP SuccessFactors provides a comprehensive HCM solution that can drive business success.

This post completes a 3-part series intended to help speed your HCM move to the cloud in 2024. 

In Part 1 of this blog series, we reviewed the SAP Readiness Check for SAP SuccessFactors solutions

In Part 2 of this blog series, we showcased the SAP HCM Evolution Kit workshop

In conclusion, the SAP HCM ROI Calculator is a game-changer for organizations considering a move to SAP SuccessFactors. With a typical 107% return on investment and a user-friendly interface, it's a valuable tool for anyone looking to understand the potential financial benefits of making the switch. Don't miss out on this opportunity to gain insights into the economic benefits of moving from SAP ERP HCM to SAP SuccessFactors – please try the calculator today and see how it can help your organization!

entry.title: Prepare your Selective Data Transfer to SAP Cloud ALM with SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Dear All,

Note: This blog describes the addition of the Scope Analysis for Selective Data Transfer capability available within SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM. You may refer to this blog for an overview of the other checks available in SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM.

This blog was updated on 6/04/2025 with information about the new matrix "Used Solution Documentation Relations" - see the Branch Data section.

Today, we are excited to announce that SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM has been extended to provide insights into solution documentation data in an SAP Solution Manager system in preparation for a solution documentation Selective Data Transfer project.

With the Selective Data Transfer tool in SAP Solution Manager, you can select and extract the data in a format compatible with SAP Cloud ALM. The process to transfer the data is structured in the following steps:

  • Step 1: Process hierarchy (folder, scenario, organizational unit, master data)
  • Step 2: Process steps and executables
  • Step 3: Business processes and diagrams
  • Step 4: Documents and test steps

The new Scope Analysis for Selective Data Transfer allows one to view all solutions and branches in the analyzed SAP Solution Manager system, providing the necessary insights to select a source branch for a Selective Data Transfer project from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM.

Scope Analysis for Selective Data Transfer - Overview

The overview in the dashboard summarizes the total number of solutions and branches in the SAP Solution Manager system. Additionally, the bar chart displays the total number of changes to the elements within the branches. You can switch between views showing the last 6 or 12 months to see the aggregated number of changes to branches within these two time periods. The chart displays the top 5 solutions, based on the number of changes. When you navigate to the detail page of this analysis, you can see the aggregated number of changes for all solutions.

 For more information about Selective Data Transfer from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM, see Transition to SAP Cloud ALM for Implementation in SAP Support Portal.

Scope Analysis for Selective Data Transfer - Details

The detailed view provides information for all solutions in the analyzed system, including a summary of the changes to solution documentation elements recorded in the solution documentation history. You may navigate the solutions using the sidebar panel on the left side of the page. When you select a solution in the sidebar, the details of the solution are presented in the content panel. For each solution, the following information is displayed:

  • Solution Data: This tab displays general information for the solution, including created logical component groups, solution settings, public scopes, used custom attributes, and used business partner attributes relevant to preparing SAP Cloud ALM for the data transfer from SAP Solution Manager.
  • Branches: A tab for each branch in the solution displays the solution documentation elements that are part of each Selective Data Transfer process step. The details include the number of objects within the specific branch and the number of changes recorded in the last 6 or 12 months from when the data collector ran in the SAP Solution Manager system.
    In the case of Step 4 of the Selective Data Transfer process, the number of documents and test steps, along with the total size in mebibytes (1 Mebibyte = 1.024^2 bytes), are displayed.
    The analysis also shows which solution documentation elements aren’t part of the selective data transfer process. These objects are excluded because an export tool is not planned or there is no equivalent entity in SAP Cloud ALM to support the import.
    The list of used logical component groups provides insight into which group is referenced by at least one solution documentation element within the corresponding branch.

Solution Data

This section displays general information for the solution, like the created logical component groups, solution settings, public scopes, used custom attributes, and used business partner attributes relevant to preparing SAP Cloud ALM for the data transfer from SAP Solution Manager.

Additionally, this section presents the configurations and customizations that need to be adapted or mapped to correctly transfer the selected branch data into SAP Cloud ALM.

 The following configurations are displayed in this tab for the selected solution:

  • Logical Component Groups: Displays a table with the logical component groups created in the selected solution, with the information on whether sites are enabled and if the logical component group is referenced for any solution documentation element in any branch within the solution.
  • Configurations:
    • Document types: Provides the number of custom document types in use.
    • Status Schemas: Provides the number of custom status schemas in use.
    • Content Languages: Provides a list of languages active in the solution.
  • Scopes: Shows the list of public scopes that exist in the solution.
  • Custom Attributes: Shows the list of custom attributes in use.
  • Business Partner Attributes: Shows the list of related business partner attributes used by at least one document in the solution.

Branch Data

This section details the solution documentation elements of each step within the Selective Data Transfer process. The details include the number of objects in a branch and the number of changes recorded 6 or 12 months before the data collection in the SAP Solution Manager system.

Additionally, it includes the list of elements from the solution documentation that aren’t part of the selective data transfer process. These objects are excluded because an export tool is not planned or there is no equivalent entity in SAP Cloud ALM to support the import.

The information for each branch is displayed in the same structure as the Selective Data Transfer process is expected to run. The details provide insights into how each branch is used, the elements changed in the last 6 or 12 months, and the expected sizing the future content management server should have to support the documents from the SAP Solution Manager system.

 

The number of changes for all solution documentation elements is obtained from the history of the solutions, and the figures for the last 6 or 12 months are calculated from the data collection date.

Note: The solution documentation elements in and out of scope depend on the current SAP Solution Manager transition strategy to SAP Cloud ALM and may change anytime.

Update on 6/04/2025:

The branch section now shows a matrix with the relation between the elements in solution documentation that are used and supported by both SAP Cloud ALM and the Selective Data Transfer Tool. The matrix shows where the branch contains data for these relations and combination with the availability, it helps to determine if the complete transfer of the solution documentation to SAP Cloud ALM using the Selective Data Transfer tool is possible.

Data Collection

The SAP Solution Manager data collector has been updated to include the required data for the new Scope Analysis for Selective Data Transfer capability. Ensure that version 31 (or higher) of SAP Note 3236443 is implemented before running the collector program in your SAP Solution Manager system. You can either create a new SAP Readiness Check analysis or update an existing analysis using the Update Analysis function to upload the enhanced data collection archive.  

As always, we look forward to receiving your feedback!

Your SAP Readiness Check Team

entry.title: New SAP Activate road map version "24Q3 " – Transition to SAP S/4HANA (on premise)
entry.content:
We are happy to announce the new release of the SAP Activate Methodology for Transition to SAP S/4HANA, the implementation roadmap which is intended to guide the project team step by step through the implementation of SAP S/4HANA on premise.

What we have changed for you:

  • Many new / updated accelerators linking you to great information sources you probably would miss otherwise. Want some examples?
    • SAP Signavio customers can import and use an interactive "Activate Accelerator" which is describing in detail how the SAP Signavio suite can support them in SAP S/4HANA implementations. 
    • Here is an updated cookbook on "Employee Business Partner Integration".
    • Don't miss the updated "Manifesto for senior IT leadership". Although targeting to private cloud, on premise customers can easily identify what is relevant for them.
    • We added information on "SAP Cloud ALM vs. SolMan". In case you go with SAP Cloud ALM, this Best Practice document provides information also for on premise implementations (compressed on 300 pages). 
    • What I like very much is the SAP BTP Guidance Framework. It bundles information for both architects and developers: Architecture guidance, methodologies and developer guides are right next to each other.
  • The whole topic of enablement / learning has been restructured. It is now harmonized across the roadmaps in SAP Activate.
  • We also enhanced the content for system conversion. You will find new activities / tasks like "Conversion Readiness Assessment" or "Decide on Conversion Strategy", and we will continue on this topic in future.

You can find the new release of the “Transition to SAP S/4HANA” roadmap in the “SAP Roadmap Viewer”. And as you already know, we will push the updated content into SAP Cloud ALM for you within the upcoming days.

Hopefully you will enjoy it!

entry.title: New Release of SAP Activate Methodology for SAP S/4HANA upgrades
entry.content:
Dear All,

we are happy to announce the new release of the upgrade roadmap for SAP S/4HANA (on premise), the SAP Activate Methodology for SAP S/4HANA upgrades.

Note: We have also updated the implementation roadmap for SAP S/4HANA (on premise), if you want to see the details, check this blog.

In this new release of the roadmap for SAP S/4HANA upgrades, we focussed on the topic of enablement / learning which has been restructured. It is now harmonized across all the roadmaps in SAP Activate.

In addition, we added some thoughts about introducing Artificial Intelligence with the next upgrade and introduced the PE service offerings AI Strategy service and Architecture Point of View: Artificial Intelligence.

Are you already in the middle of your upgrade project and use the roadmap tasks in SAP Cloud ALM? Here is how you can check the updates we delivered with the new roadmap release:

On the Overview page in SAP Cloud ALM for Project and Task Management, you find the tile "SAP Content Update Summary".

This card displays the number of new, updated, and obsolete tasks that are part of the last roadmap update in context with your project. By reviewing this summary, you can quickly identify the changes and take the necessary actions in your project. Simply click on the bubbles to review the task list. Whenever an update is made to the roadmap tasks, project leads also receive a recommendation with 'Warning' prompt, to assign a team member as 'Responsible' for the new tasks.

For further details, check this blog.

As always, we are interested in your feedback!

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Migration: Insights and Guidance for IT Leaders
entry.content:
As organizations worldwide continue to navigate the complexities of digital transformation, many that still rely on SAP ERP or the on-premises version of SAP S/4HANA are considering a major change: migrating to the cloud. This move isn’t just about a technical upgrade; it’s a strategic decision that could shape the future of your business. To help you get started, we’ve completely updated our guide, Mapping Your Journey to SAP S/4HANA, with practical insights, step-by-step instructions, best practices, and detailed background information.

Keeping up with the fast pace of digital change isn’t just beneficial — it’s essential. Industries like automotive, with their complex supply chains, clearly demonstrate the risks of not adapting quickly. That’s exactly why we created the original guide back in 2018, which quickly became a go-to resource for many companies. Now, I’m excited to share that we’ve just released a fully updated edition.

This edition brings together insights from dozens of SAP experts across the company, each sharing their unique perspectives and experiences. Inside, you’ll find a comprehensive guide that covers every aspect of the transition to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. We’ve focused on the key technology elements to help IT decision-makers confidently plan their roadmap, avoid common pitfalls, and ensure a smooth path to a successful go-live.

What makes this guide special is the wealth of knowledge it offers — drawn from thousands of successful transformation projects. It’s more than just a collection of tips; it’s packed with real-world experience, brought to life with clear text and visuals. Since every project is unique, we’ve included plenty of links to additional resources so you can rely on this guide at every step of your migration journey. The feedback from our customers speaks for itself: the guide has been downloaded more than 180,000 times since it was first published.

Why an update to our key reference

You may be wondering why a new edition, and why now? As one of the co-authors, I can tell you that while we’ve always kept the guide up to date, the past six years have seen major changes in the SAP landscape. New tools and methods have emerged, and our RISE with SAP offering has grown significantly. These developments have changed the way we help customers move to Cloud ERP, so it’s the perfect time to update the guide with these innovations and the valuable feedback we’ve received from our customers and partners.

Our goal with this guide remains the same: to give IT leaders everything they need in one place to successfully implement SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. We've carefully organized the guide into three key chapters.

1. Strategic decisions

In the first chapter, we’ll help you make smart choices about the transition. We cover everything from deciding between public and private cloud options to understanding the unique benefits of the GROW with SAP and RISE with SAP programs, and even navigating the complexities of cloud operations.

2. Ingredients for project success

The middle section delves into the critical factors that determine the success of your project. We discuss change management, knowledge management, customer and supplier master data integration, the partner ecosystem, and more.

3. Essential tools from SAP

The final chapter provides an in-depth look at the 15 most important tools available to help you assess your systems, plan and execute the migration, and track project progress. These include SAP Data Services, SAP Readiness Check, ABAP development tools, and the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit.

More than just a guide, Mapping Your Journey to SAP S/4HANA is your trusted companion as an IT leader navigating a complex transformation. Whether you’re diving into the theory or need practical tips to keep your organization on track beyond 2027, this guide has you covered. You can read it cover to cover for a complete understanding or use it as a quick reference for specific stages or challenges.

I invite you to download it today and take the next step in your digital transformation journey: Download now

entry.title: Insights into Change Request Management usage with SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Please note: The following blog describes the new Change Request Management Insights functionality available within SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM. You may also refer to the other blogs about features in SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM:

Prepare your Selective Data Transfer to SAP Cloud ALM with SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM

Service and Administration Capabilities in SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM

SAP supports your transition to SAP Cloud ALM with SAP Readiness Check

Availability of SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM

 

Dear All,

Today, we are excited to announce that SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM now provides additional insights into the usage of Change Request Management capabilities in an SAP Solution Manager system to support the planning of the transition of your change-controlled landscapes to SAP Cloud ALM.

The new Change Request Management Insights check reads and collects the usage details for all active change cycles in your SAP Solution Manager system. It allows you to quickly identify the usage of individual change request management capabilities within each cycle and see which systems of your landscape are managed by each cycle.

Change Request Management Insights - Overview

The chart in the dashboard card summarizes the total change documents created within the active cycles,  aggregated by transaction type. This chart provides an overview of the change types being managed within the change cycles in your change-controlled landscapes. Note that only active cycles at the time of the data collector run are used to create this analysis. The data collector ignores closed change cycles; as a result, they are not considered within the statistics displayed in the findings of this check.

Select any item from the pie chart or the dashboard card header to open the detail view.

 

Change Request Management Insights - Details

The detail view provides complete usage figures for the analyzed change cycles. The information includes, for example, the aggregated number of change documents and transport requests, the integration of change documents with Solution Documentation, and the number of tracks the cycle controls.

The provided details help identify the change cycles that control most of the changes, where large or complex landscapes are being managed, and which change cycles use complex change request management scenarios. These insights help to plan the transition to SAP Cloud ALM. For example, it might be advisable to start with transitioning simple landscapes and continue with other more complex landscapes at a later stage.

The two charts on top of the detail view provide filtering options for the Items table below:

  • You can filter by Active Change Cycle Type by selecting a type in the pie chart at the top-left of the page.
  • The Usage of Change Request Management Capabilities Across Cycles chart at the top-right of the page allows for the filtering of the Items table based on capability.

 

Additional Information for Change Cycles

For each change cycle in the table, click the number of a Cycle ID to open a side panel with additional insights. This panel provides the details of the tracks, showing the systems and roles that are part of the change-controlled landscape. In addition, it shows how many Requests for Change and Change Documents have been created within the cycle, aggregated by transaction type. The Usage section of the panel provides the date of the latest usage of the individual change request management capabilities, helping to identify those capabilities not used recently.

The SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM scenario already provides details for the availability of equivalent capabilities in SAP Cloud ALM for each displayed change request management capability. To see if required capabilities are already available or planned in SAP Cloud ALM, you can navigate directly to the Availability of Relevant Capabilities dashboard using the provided link at the bottom of the Usage section within the right-side panel.

Data Collection

The SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM data collector, which runs in SAP Solution Manager, has been updated to include the required data for the new Change Request Management Insights capability. Ensure version 43 (or higher) of SAP Note 3236443 has been implemented before scheduling the collector. Once the data collector is complete, you can use the generated data archive to create a new SAP Readiness Check analysis or update an existing analysis (using the Update Analysis function to upload the enhanced data collection archive).

As always, we look forward to receiving your feedback!

Your SAP Readiness Check Team

entry.title: Compatibility Scope Matrix for Production Planning.. 2025 is around the corner!!
entry.content:
The Readiness Check Report helps us understand the mandatory changes when moving from ECC to S/4HANA or just upgrading to the newest version on S/4HANA. Through this information, all the customers will be able to plan their projects accordingly to have the system ready for a smooth transition. From a functional perspective, this report shows us 2 main pieces of information, the first one is the Simplification Item list, which highlights the mandatory changes and the items that are out of the architecture target in S/4HANA and won't be considered for further innovations. The second one is the Compatibility Scope Matrix, which lists the compatibility packages (CP), this contains the details of the functionalities that have a limited use right to SAP S/4HANA and recommends the solution alternative and the strategy to move forward.

This blog will explain the common items relevant as part of the compatibility scope under the Production Planning module, describing the details and the alternative function to be considered when replacing it. Functions that are part of the compatibility scope can be used just until the expiry date of the compatibility pack license, meaning at the end of 2025. Even when SAP recently announced the maintenance extension for SAP Business Suite 7 until the end of 2027, the usage rights of the compatibility packs were not included in this extension.

Luckily and because the complexity of each item, there is a specific extension of compatibility scope usage rights for a few modules until 2030. Under manufacturing, this applies to selected items under the component of Production Planning in Process Industry (PP-PI). If you are interested in checking the full details list of the compatibility Scope Matrix please review the attachments of SAP Note 2269324. There you will find the components marked with (D), meaning whose are the items relevant for the extension.

My intention through this blog is to mainly aware and remind all the readers about what items are relevant considering the timing! But in the end, is up to each customer to decide when they will keep it or will start to migrate to the designated alternative functionality. The decision, of at which point in time this will be done, should be taken early in advance to plan accordingly for the migration efforts!! Keep in mind the end of 2025 is around the corner!!

Now, let’s get started and finally introduce some of the items for the Production Planning scope. Keep in mind this list doesn't contain a description of all of them, just explains the common items that I typically see relevant, based on my experiences with multiple customers.

  • Classical MRP list: This is one of the main items, and in most cases applies to those customers who are still running the classic MRP as part of their process. The majority decided to keep it due to the restriction by using MRP live and/or some custom developments where MRP list tables need to be read. In S/4HANA the MRP live code has an optimized logic, where is no longer needed the creation of an MRP list without causing a huge concern from a performance point of view. In addition, the evaluation based on the MRP list isn't optimal because is not going to consider new requirements that could be created meanwhile the finished of the MRP run and the real-time when the planners have to do the checking, because is just and snapshot of the result.

In general, the creation of the MRP list by running the classic MRP won't be possible anymore after the end of 2025, but the classic MPR will still work for those customers that have other restrictions to be considered before moving to MRP live.

Now what happens if we still need the MRP list creation? The best suggestion will be to check always read stock/requirements lists via API MD_MDPSX_READ_API or BAPI BAPI_MATERIAL_STOCK_REQ_LIST., as suggested in the SAP Note 2268085. In addition, SAP offers the standard report RMDMRPEXTRACT01, which extracts the planning data and saves it into a custom table, similar to the results generated by the MRP list. You can find more information about the MRP lust alternative by checking the blog MRP Lists are gone with MRP Live! What should I do now?

  • Flow Manufacturing: Flow manufacturing in ERP includes functions for line design, line balancing as well and rate/takt-based sequence planning. It is part of repetitive manufacturing solution and only suitable for repetitive manufacturing planned orders. Because is now part of the compatibility scope, means that you need to migrate from ERP line design, ERP line balancing, and ERP sequence planning to its designated alternative functionality which is now fully covered by PPDS model mix planning and sequencing.
  • Graphical Planning Table: Currently there are a bunch of troubles and open incidents due to the complexity when managing the chart and graphical planning tables provided in SAP GUI. Even when the transactions CM21, CM22, CM23, CM25, with graphical planning table or Gantt Chart are still available in SAP S/4HANA on-premise are not part of the target architecture in S/4HANA and remain as obsolete. To have a better user experience and make easier the understanding and the analysis by the planners, the recommendation is to replace those by using new Fiori Apps like "Manage Work Center Capacity", "Capacity Scheduling Table", and "Capacity Scheduling Board" in SAP S/4HANA. If you are interested in knowing more about this new application on PP-CP, please check my previous blog: Did you know this about Capacity Planning in S/4HANA?

In addition, you can consider SAP Digital Manufacturing Cloud - DMC component Resource Orchestration REO. REO works on more granular data defined in DMC. In a job-shop environment, for example, work-centers could be defined in SAP S/4HANA and the individual machines only in DMC.

Last but not least, is important to know you can also have the possible to use embedded PP/DS if exists complex scheduling problems, for example, planned and production orders of different BOM levels need to be synchronized, or if material availability needs to be considered in scheduling, or if multiple bottleneck resources must be aligned by optimizing the schedule.

  • Logistics Information System In PP:  LIS data can be analyzed based on statistical data, which is contained in "information structures". Important key figures are directly updated from the operative application to the information structures. Where historically, Historically, following LIS tables (mentioned below) were used for standard or custom reports in Production Planning (S021, SFIS,  S022, SFIS, S023, SFIS, S024, and S026). However, LIS in PP is part of the S/4HANA compatibility pack and even when you can continue using LIS tables, and are available, won’t be considered as part of the new technologies anymore.

Considering future production analytics will be based on HANA, CDS views will be able to aggregate transactional data dynamically, and powerful analytical UIs for multi-dimensional reporting, resulting in the best option to replace the current LIS. Once switching you will note improvements in the performance of many transactions (fewer tables to update, fewer locking conflicts) and less memory consumption. Please refer to the following blog for further information: Custom Analytical Queries as an alternative for LIS in SAP S/4HANA Production Planning (PP)

  • Forecast-Based Planning: Forecast-based planning (MRP type VV) is not strategic anymore within SAP S/4HANA and should be avoided if possible. This is because the MRP creates planned orders or purchase requisitions if the total forecast demand up to a certain point of time exceeds the total firmed receipt quantity up to the same point of time. The total firmed receipt quantity includes inventory, production orders, purchase orders, firmed planned orders, and firmed purchase requisitions.

An alternative exists and is by using PIRs (Planned Independent Requirement) instead of forecast demands. Provides several advantages in S/4, allowing benefits like APIs available to handle PIRs, new FIORI-apps like 'Maintain PIRs' for better management, PIRs allow for consumption with sales demands and dependent requirements or stock transfer demands, the possibility to split PIRS and re-organize unused PIR demands.

So what should we do if MRP type VV is still in place? First, convert forecast requirements into planned independent requirements (PIR) and then change MRP type VV to one of the MRP types as PD, P1, P2, P3, or P4 which doesn’t have direct consideration of forecast.

  • Control Recipes/Instructions: Due to the several improvements in the used communication technology (currently via t-RFC), the usage of control recipes/control instructions in conjunction with browser-based PI sheets and work instructions is part of the SAP S/4HANA compatibility scope. As an alternative, it is possible to keep using the control recipes/control instructions in conjunction with linking process control systems and other external systems by using Manufacturing Execution Connect (classic).

SAP S/4HANA provides new Process Order integration capabilities with new SOAP and oData APIs, where the Control Instruction capabilities will be offered now as part of SAP Digital Manufacturing Cloud and can be sent to MES, e.g. to SAP Digital Manufacturing Cloud, with new SOAP APIs. Please refer to  SAP S/4HANA Feature Scope Description or note 3035649 FAQ : Manufacturing Execution Connect (classic).

A similar recommendation applies for Process Messages, also an item relevant for PP in compatibility scope, you can check further details on the SAP Note 2270231

  • Process Instruction Sheets: Browser-based PI sheets are used in the regulated environment (pharmaceutical production, and so on) to control and track the production execution. The content of the PI Sheet/Work Instruction is rendered as plain HTML and displayed in the SAP HTML Viewer of ABAP SAP GUI screens and depends on MS Internet Explorer. The new architecture recommends the usage of Digital Manufacturing Cloud’s (DMC) Production Operator Dashboard (POD) which provides similar functionality as PI-sheets. It will allow displaying Work Instructions, recording of actual data, and enforcing predefined production processes.

Please be careful and after switching from browser-based PI Sheets/Electronic Work Instructions to SAP DMC, remember to check your custom code in the context of data transfer from browser-based PI Sheets/Electronic Work Instructions to whatever receiver and clean up your custom code that makes use of this functionality.

Hope you find helpful the information provided in terms of understanding the compatibility pack and start to think about the action plan to complete the replacement of the function and adopt the S/4HANA strategy within the given timeline.

Further information:

SAP Support Portal

The Future of Compatibility Packs in SAP S/4HANA

Do not forget to follow us via @SAP and #S4HANA, or myself via @Jennicherrera and LinkedIn: Jennifer Carolina Herrera Suárez | LinkedIn

Have a nice day!

Regards

Jennifer

entry.title: SAP supports your transition to SAP Cloud ALM with SAP Readiness Check
entry.content:
Please note: The following blog  recaps the SAP ALM Summit EMEA in autumn 2024, where the transition journey from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM, supported by SAP Readiness Check, was a central topic.

For information about features  and functionality of SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM, you may also refer to the following blogs:

Prepare your Selective Data Transfer to SAP Cloud ALM with SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM

Insights into Change Request Management usage with SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM

Service and Administration Capabilities in SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM

Availability of SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM

 

One central topic on the SAP ALM Summit EMEA in autumn 2024 was the transition journey from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM, supported by SAP Readiness Check.

You may recap the SAP ALM Summit EMEA sessions on youtube:

  • Fire up your transition journey with SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM
  • What you need to know for a successful transition to SAP Cloud ALM
  • Prepare your transition from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM 

 

SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM - Introduction

With SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM, SAP provides a self-service tool to analyze an existing SAP Solution Manager system in preparation for a transition to SAP Cloud ALM. SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM helps customers to better understand the usage of their SAP Solution Manager system, and to plan and scope the transition of application lifecycle management capabilities to SAP Cloud ALM. This transition can be performed either completely or by taking a capability-by-capability approach. SAP Readiness Check provides a mapping of equivalent capabilities between SAP Solution Manager and SAP Cloud ALM, while also showing the availability status of capabilities in SAP Cloud ALM. It also helps customers to engage with partners and SAP to discuss options for the most appropriate transition plan.

Learn more in this blog post and the following assets:

  • Get started with the SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM (SAP Note 3236443)
  • E-Learning: Introduction to SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM

 

SAP Activate Roadmap "Transition to SAP Cloud ALM"

The SAP Activate roadmap provides comprehensive guidance on the transition from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM in the well-known format of SAP Activate Best Practices. Read the Transition Planning deliverable in the Discover phase to learn how SAP Readiness Check supports the transition from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM, and the underlying tasks:

  1. Perform SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM
  2. Define Project Scope and Objectives
  3. Define capability scope for transition to SAP Cloud ALM

Go to the SAP Activate Roadmap

 

Services for SAP Cloud ALM

SAP offers services which help you with your transition to SAP Cloud ALM:

  • Services for SAP Cloud ALM

Check the Application Lifecycle Management page for Transition to SAP Cloud ALM  to learn more, from the strategy overview and a functional comparison of SAP Solution Manager and SAP Cloud ALM, to recommended transition steps and transition support.

entry.title: Business Partner Synchronization: defining the phases of conversion
entry.content:
Introduction

When migrating from SAP ECC to S/4HANA, there are preparatory steps that need to be done before the actual system conversion. There may be some clients that even prefer to have the pre-conversion steps implemented through pre-projects before closing the deal with the ultimate conversion project, as mentioned here. This is widely recommended especially because some of these steps don’t affect the day-to-day system functionality and can be implemented without impact on SAP ERP. Nonetheless, in all possible project scenarios, the customer/vendor synchronization is mandatory as a pre-conversion step for S/4HANA conversion due to the Business Partner Approach, meaning that the business partner is now the leading object for legal entities. Being so, the BP synchronization can be achieved by following the steps of the well-known KBA 2713963. When doing this activity for a big pharmaceutical client in Brazil, I have faced a complex scenario where I had to elaborate a flowchart to facilitate the definition of phases of conversion, which appeared difficult to assess at first glance. In this blog post I am going to disclose details about this flowchart to help others that may have the same complex scenario.

 

The scenarios

1. Keep the same numbers between BP and customer/vendor 

A question that must be answered is if there is a desire to keep the business partner and the customer/vendor with the same number. This means that when maintaining the entity’s master data in transaction BP, the number entered is the same used in the creation of transactional documents.

In the above example, customer 11 has the same number as its BP, but the vendor doesn’t. If it is not mandatory to keep the same one, then the BP range number can be configured independently, and the BP conversion is not complex in terms of number assignment. But if there is the desire to keep all possible numbers the same, then an analysis must be done of the current account groups range number customizing, using transaction OBAR and OBAS together with XDN1 and XKN1, which may culminate in the next scenarios.

2. Customers/vendors out of the current customized number range

As well described in SAP documentations about BP conversion, all created customers/vendors are scope of the conversion, even though they are marked for deletion, unless they are archived. This means that in some scenarios, the number of an old customer or vendor may be out of date, because its account group number range could have been changed through time.

The result is existing customers/vendors with a number range different than the current customizing for its account group in OBAR/OBAS, like in the above example, where the customer highlighted is a DEBI, which is configured to numerate from 900000 to 999999, therefore its number “1” is out of date. If this is part of the project scenario, then these entities with old range numbers can have their number reassigned*.

*Of course, the number reassignment is only an option. Even though the number may be out of the current customized range, one can always do a temporary configuration just to run the BP synchronization for these customers/vendors and then configure back to the current customizing. But this could result in several phases of conversion in production system, that may not be feasible in certain clients. Also, as standard the transaction BP shows a warning message when the number range of the opened BP is out of the current number range customized, so this may not be desirable.

3. Customers and vendors with same number

The last check that can be made is if there are customers and vendors that do not belong to the same legal entity but have the same number. This happens because the account groups for customers are different elements in SAP than the account groups for vendors, meaning that they can have the same number range.

As the business partner is now the leading object and have only one central number range configured, if a customer and vendor have overlapping numbers and do not belong to the same legal entity, one of them would need to have its number reassigned, because only one corresponding BP with this number can be created. 

 

Phases of conversion

The result is two amounts of customers/vendors to be converted: those that are going to have its number kept, and those that are going to have its number reassigned. The BP conversion for these entities must be done in two phases, because they demand different number range configuration. Note that the steps for the CVI configuration regarding number ranges are very well documented on SAP S/4HANA Cookbook CVI, so in the next topics only the specific customizing are going to be commented. 

1. Customers/vendors that are going to keep the same numbers in BP

To run the synchronization in this phase, the flag “External” must be checked in BP number range transaction BUCF, and the “Same number” field must be flagged in the assignment between BP grouping and account groups, in transactions V_TBC001 and V_TBD001.There is a KBA 24303080 describing this scenario. After running the BP conversion, then the next phase can be started.

2. Customers/vendors that are going to have the BP number reassigned

In this phase, the remaining entities are going to have their number defined internally according to the BP number range customizing, so the flags described in the previous phase must be unflagged.After finishing this conversion, it is likely that for the account groups that share the same range number with BP groupings, the numbers used in BP are different than the used in account group, meaning that for the same range, the “NR Status” is different between BUCF and XDN1/XKN1.It is highly important that these numbers be equalized after the conversion. 

An important observation is to make sure to use CVI_COCKPIT filters to capture only the desired customers/vendors for each phase, being the selection by number the most recommended. Additionally, as after the conversion any new customer or vendor created in XK01 and XD01 will synchronize a BP automatically, a final request must be transported to production system to make sure those flags are back in place for the automatic BP creation. Finally, note that the BP number is only relevant to the transaction BP, meaning that the number used in transactional documents is untouched. 

 

Conclusion

In this blog post it was possible to establish a flow of questions and decisions to achieve the phases of conversion in a BP synchronization step as a SAP ECC to S/4HANA pre-conversion project.

This flowchart can be used as a guide to analyze the scope of customers/vendors' number range in client’s scenario.  

As mentioned before, the CVI conversion is very well documented by SAP and the steps of configuration and synchronization are described accurately in the official Cookbook. It is recommended that one reach this CVI Cockpit FAQ, as this is a very complete blog post that contains answers to most of possible scenarios that a client could have. 

I hope I helped you organize the thoughts regarding the range numbers on complex master data scenarios based on an experience that I had, please comment below if you have any further. questions.

entry.title: S/4Hana Brownfield Conversion Project
entry.content:
First, the system needs to be prepared, that is, the ECC system is moved to the S4 HANA structure by technical consultants (BASIS-ABAP). For this, they upload the relevant sap notes to the system and create a sandbox system. All module consultants provide testing and controls in this test system, then if necessary, the 2nd sandbox system can be installed as a development system or directly to the QA system, then the live system will be switched.

Throughout the project you will hear the following terms very often SI Check List and SI items

SI: Simplification Item.

Technical consultants run Simplification Item Check Report and if there is an error or inconsistency, they assign it to the relevant module consultants.

All module consultants check their own inconsistencies and errors and make the necessary corrections.

go to se38 /SDF/RC_START_CHECK

You can check SI ıtem and sap notes in this report

SAP Readiness Check Cloud Application

ZIP files are created and uploaded to the SAP Readiness Check Cloud App. The data here can be read by consultants and verified before being uploaded to the application.

For more information on this part, see this video published by SAP

https://support.sap.com/content/dam/SAAP/SAP_Activate/RC_Version_3.mp4

After this technical transition, module consultants start working on the transaction codes, tables, structures that change with S4 Hana in the sandbox system.

The most important topics are as follows;

-CVI integration, also called BP Configuration

-Transfer of price and credit master and credit management and control of the changing structure

For example, additional processing is required for Condition Master Data mappings because the data will now be used in the PRCD_ELEMENTS table instead of the KONV table. For more detailed information you can take a look at this note

https://me.sap.com/notes/2267308

If there is a Rebate Process, the Settlement management- conditon contract structure that comes with S/4 Hana can be recommended or not configured

If there are licensed products such as DSD, Aatp, etc., their licenses will be renewed and system connections will be made so that they can be used in S/4. For more detailed information, you can take a look at these notes

Aatp

https://me.sap.com/notes/2267745

https://me.sap.com/notes/2209696

Rebate

https://me.sap.com/notes/2267377/E

Except for these

Some data model simplifications have been implemented for the SD field. Removed status tables VBUK-VBUP instead status fields have been moved to tables VBAK and VBAP for orders, LIKP and LIPS for deliveries, VBRK for billing documents for more details https://me.sap.com/notes/2267306

Instead of S066, S067 tables used in Credit Management, UKMBP_CMS_SGM & UKMBP_CMS tables came in S/4 Hana. For more details https://me.sap.com/notes/2270544

For Customer master data, KNA1, KNB1, KNVV, KNVP tables were used in ECC System. BP master data will be created in S/4 Hana, BUT000-BP: General data I BUT100-BP: Roles tables will be used.

Apart from these, there are CVI_LINK tables. Customer-BP and Vendor-BP information is kept in these tables. When the numbers do not match, it can check through these.

Customer-BP table V_CVI_CUST_LINK

BP and Supplier table V_CVI_VEND_LINK

I would be happy to read your thoughts and comments and if there are better ways to fulfil the requirement, please leave them in the comment section below.

 

Thanks so much

entry.title: SAP Readiness Check for SAP S/4HANA now supports SAP S/4HANA private Cloud / RISE Target Versions
entry.content:
Dear All,

SAP Readiness Check for SAP S/4HANA can now be used for both SAP S/4HANA (on premise) and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (PCE/RISE) target product versions.

​SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition are developed in the same codeline and are identical concerning the relevant simplification items. Nevertheless, there are differences in the compatibility scope items and successor functionalities (for example the successor of FI-TV on premise is Travel Management, on PCE the successor is SAP Concur).

The correct target SAP S/4HANA version is selected in the dropdown list in the SAP Readiness Check data collection report RC_COLLECT_ANALYSIS_DATA:

Please note: To see the "SAP S/4HANA private Cloud" entries in the list, you may need to update your local replica of the simplification item catalog.

To determine whether any action is required, go to transaction SA38 in the system to be analyzed and run report RC_COLLECT_ANALYSIS_DATA. If the SAP S/4HANA private Cloud versions are not yet visible in the Target S/4HANA Version list, the local replica of the simplification item catalog needs to be updated.

To update the Simplification Item Catalog, perform the following steps:

    1. Execute the report /SDF/RC_START_CHECK in the source system via transaction SA38.
    2. Choose the Update Catalog with latest version from SAP button.

 As a result, the local replica of the simplification item catalog will be updated. You can now run report RC_COLLECT_ANALYSIS_DATA again, and the Target S/4HANA Version list will now include the latest generally available SAP S/4HANA product versions.

----------------

Manual Upload of the Simplification Item Catalog

Alternatively, if the SAP-SUPPORT_PORTAL RFC destination is unable to connect with the SAP support backbone, you can update the simplification item catalog content manually:

    1. Open the simplification item catalog content in SAP for Me
    2. Choose the Download Simplification Item icon to download the content to your local computer.
    3. Run the report /SDF/RC_START_CHECK.
    4. Choose the Upload Simplification Item Catalog from the file button and upload the content from where you saved it in step 2.

Now you can execute report RC_COLLECT_ANALYSIS_DATA again. The latest SAP S/4HANA product versions will now be visible in the Target S/4HANA Version list. Proceed as described in SAP Note 2913617 (SAP S/4HANA conversions) or SAP Note 3059197 (SAP S/4HANA upgrades) to perform the data collection and create the new analysis.

entry.title: Helpful links for your SAP transformation
entry.content:
The architecture chapter can use and recommend the tools and services below to guide and equip (and create principles and guardrails to) professionals and managers to support evidence-based decisions for your business and digital transformations.

The links below can help to provide visibility and clarity of your SAP ecosystem, especially to non-SAP professionals and leaders, so they can also make better questions when discovering and exploring the myriad of capabilities that SAP can offer.

You will need an SAP S-user (me.sap.com) and an SAP account (sap.com) to access the content.

  • SAP Best Practices based on SAP Signavio Process Navigator, alternatively, SAP Signavio Process Explorer is the gateway to get insights into SAP’s process portfolio and leverage related process implementation guidance and reference business and solution architectures. These include business-capability and solution maps, process models, metrics, industry best practices, and SAP best-practice and product recommendations.

 

 

  • SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library to explore, plan and implement SAP Fiori, the latest user experience from SAP including all relevant content for the SAP Fiori launchpad.

 

  • SAP Business Technology Platform to explore and understand different architecture patterns which can be implemented using SAP BTP services.

 

  • SAP BTP Guidance Framework for architects, developers, and administrators.

 

  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub (or Intelligent Enterprise Reference Solution Architecture) to help discover, consume, and create integrations, extensions, and innovations.

 

  • SAP Activate provides a clear guided methodology to deploy, adopt and extend new capabilities with different approaches, e.g., agile or waterfall, cloud, hybrid or on-premise, implementation or upgrade.

 

  • SAP Road Maps support the journey to SAP’s future product portfolio. Before customising, check for future enhancements.

 

  • SAP Customer Influence offers a range of programs that give customers the opportunity to influence SAP software development decisions, request specific enhancements or features, and adopt new innovations early on. Before customising, check (and vote) for opportunities and ideas to speed up SAP’s development and delivery of new requirements. Customers should engage the SAP account team to work internally with the development and product management teams.

 

  • SAP Secure Operations Map ensures smooth operation of SAP solutions by taking action proactively, before severe security problems occur.

 

 

Depending on use case, when the company is ready for transformational initiatives, use the tools and services available to customers:

  • SAP Value Lifecycle Manager for a value analysis, total costs of ownership calculation and more.

 

  • SAP Readiness Check conducts a detailed analysis of our existing SAP system to help plan our digital transformation. For example, SAP S/4HANA Conversion, SAP S/4HANA Upgrade, SAP BW/4HANA Conversion, SAP ERP Usage and Data Profiling, SAP Customer Experience Solutions, SAP SuccessFactors Solutions, SAP Cloud ALM, SAP Datasphere, SAP BW Bridge.

 

  • SAP Custom Code Analytics uses aggregated Custom Code Management (CCM) data from your SAP Solution Manager. The application gives an overview about the custom code footprint of the ABAP systems and provides insights about code quality and usage.

 

  • SAP Continuous Quality Check & Improvement Services are included in the SAP Enterprise Support contract. After each service, you receive a service report with an executive summary, findings and a detailed action plan to mitigate risks or improve your situation.

 

  • SAP Customer Evolution Kit for cost-free engagement to accelerate digital transformation to the cloud.

 

  • SAP Signavio, Process Insights, discovery edition, the successor of Process Discovery and Pathfinder on Spotlight, can get innovation recommendations based on the usage of the current system.

 

  • SAP AppHaus and its network partners offer different engagement types. From discovering innovation opportunities like rethinking business processes and user interfaces to delivering scalable solutions.

 

  • SAP Cloud Appliance Library offers a quick and easy way to create SAP workloads in our cloud infrastructure.

 

  • SAP Digital Discovery and Assessment is used to plan the scope of a planned SAP S/4HANA project (for SAP partners only).
  • SAP Simplification Item Catalogue helps better prepare for the transition to SAP S/4HANA and SAP BW/4HANA. It provides a description of all relevant changes that might have an impact when converting from SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA or SAP BW to SAP BW/4HANA.

 

  • SAP Extensibility Explorer for SAP S/4HANA Cloud covers a broad spectrum of topics that allow us to adapt standard business software to our business needs by leveraging the extensibility patterns and sample scenarios from SAP.

 

 

When customising is required (Clean Core), refer to the following frameworks and additional resources:

  • SAP Store is a digital marketplace with over 2000+ extensions where we can discover, try, and buy solutions from SAP partners.

 

  • SAP Partner Finder to find the best SAP partners to meet our needs.

 

  • SAP Cloud Application Programming Model helps build cloud-native applications with maximised productivity at minimised costs, based on proven best practices served out of the box.

 

  • SAP UI Development Toolkit for HTML5 is a platform for developing rich user interfaces for modern web business applications.

 

  • SAP Learning offers free online courses, tutorials, trials, and official SAP help documentation for anyone who wants to build in-demand SAP skills and prepare for SAP certifications.

 

  • SAP Community offers access to experts, knowledge sharing, the latest news, resources, and insights on SAP solutions and technologies.

 

  • SAP for Me is the digital companion to interact with SAP and aggregates important alerts, metrics, and insights about the SAP product portfolio with a single access point.

 

  • Microsoft Azure Architecture Centre on guidance for architecting solutions on Azure using established patterns and practices, including SAP on Azure (as Microsoft is our strategic partner).

 

I hope it also helps guide and drive your project. It is a starting point to prepare your colleagues to support business and tech decisions.

Surely I missed many helpful links here, so feel free to add yours in the comments too. Thanks!

Originally posted on LinkedIn.

entry.title: Release of the New Scenario SAP Readiness Check for SAP Supply Chain Solutions
entry.content:
As SAP Advanced Planning and Optimization (SAP APO) is a component of SAP Supply Chain Management (SAP SCM), and SAP SCM 7.0 will reach the end of mainstream maintenance in the coming years, customers need to plan and migrate from SAP APO to SAP Integrated Business Planning (SAP IBP), leverage the integrated supply chain planning functionality within SAP S/4HANA, or a combination of both.

Today, we proudly announce the general availability of SAP Readiness Check for SAP Supply Chain solutions to assist in planning this transformation. This new SAP Readiness Check scenario provides customers and their partners with insightful information on how SAP APO is used today.

By analysing active SAP APO modules, SAP Readiness Check for SAP Supply Chain solutions supports the definition of the target solution architecture.

SAP Readiness Check for SAP Supply Chain solutions provides customers, implementation partners, and SAP consultants visibility on how the existing SAP APO modules, like SAP APO Demand Planning, SAP APO Supply Network Planning, SAP APO Production Planning and Detailed Scheduling, and Global Available-to-Promise, are implemented, tailored, and consumed.

Unlike the existing verification points presented by SAP Readiness Check for SAP S/4HANA, where the checks reveal “must-dos” in support of a possible conversion project to SAP S/4HANA, SAP Readiness Check for SAP Supply Chain solutions is purely informative and is intended to be used as input for discussions between customers, their partners, and SAP to identify the best-fitting target architecture, as well as to help scope initial effort estimations.

What is SAP Integrated Business Planning (SAP IBP)?

The SAP Integrated Business Planning (SAP IBP) solution is a cloud-based supply chain planning solution that scales to accommodate business growth and integrates with other SAP and third-party systems. It integrates key aspects of the planning process, including demand, supply, inventory, and sales and operations planning (S&OP). Designed to help you streamline planning and improve performance, SAP IBP supports data-driven decision-making and simplified collaboration to increase operational efficiency. SAP IBP delivers this with the help of advanced analytics, artificial intelligence, and powerful optimisation algorithms that enable real-time visibility, better forecasting, and faster decision-making across the entire supply chain.
For further information, check the SAP Integrated Business Planning Community.

Supply chain planning functionality available in SAP S/4HANA

  • SAP S/4HANA ePPDS
