    SAP S/4HANA offers Embedded PP/DS, which brings the SAP APO capabilities into the SAP ERP core. Embedded PP/DS brings many advantages, such as simplified master data maintenance, simplified integration, and planning PP/DS materials in MRP Live.
    The major innovation, however, is related to the user interface with SAP Fiori apps for capacity monitoring and capacity leveling. The SAP Fiori app Monitor Capacity Utilization provides an overview of the capacity load in the resources assigned to the area of responsibility and a detailed capacity overview of a selected resource, including charts and additional details of the capacity load.
    For further information, see S/4HANA Embedded PP/DS: Shift Maintenance in Monitor Capacity Fiori App. | SAP Blogs
  • SAP S/4HANA aATP
    Advanced Available-to-Promise (aATP) is a business function in SAP S/4HANA that responds to order fulfillment requests in Sales and Production Planning.
    An order fulfillment request consists of the required material, plant, requested quantity, and material availability date. The response to the request is based on the current stock situation,  future stock receipts, and real-time orders.
    Furthermore, additional restrictions can be applied based on other order attributes (like region or customers). The ATP function generates confirmation proposals for the requested material and plant, including confirmed quantities and dates.
    For further information, see Advanced Available-to-Promise (aATP) | SAP Help Portal.

 

SAP Readiness Check for SAP Supply Chain solutions

Overview
The dashboard contains the following three tiles:

  • Master Data: Shows a summary of active SAP SCM master data components, their identified dependent levels, and the corresponding data volumes in the analyzed system.
  • Key Data by Application Area: Provides insights into the key data of the different SCM components used in the analyzed system. This analysis can help to define the target system architecture and the main processes to be activated.
  • System Configuration Settings: Offers a summary of the main settings active in the analyzed system to identify requirements for the future solution architecture.

Master Data
The Master Data tile provides the top 6 objects, while the detail view provides insights into all active objects.

The detail view shows the active master data objects and the number of entries, together with additional details like table name, number of objects created last year, and number of user-created objects over the past year. The table can be exported, including all the detailed information provided.

Key Data by Application Area
This tile provides insights into the key data of the different SAP SCM components used within the analyzed system. This analysis helps to define the target system architecture by highlighting the scope and scale of the active capabilities, thus delivering input to the complexity of the data migration project.

The detail view shows the application areas in use for:

  • Demand Planning (DP)
  • Supply Planning (SNP)
  • Capable-to-Match (CTM)
  • Global Available-to-Promise (GATP)
  • Production Planning and Detailed Scheduling (PP/DS)
  • APO Documents

The object level detail helps define what data may need to be replicated to the target SAP Supply Chain solution.

System Configuration Settings
This tile provides an immediate high-level overview of the scenarios used within the system and the relevance of the analyzed objects, supporting the identification of recommended target solutions.

The following configuration settings are considered during the SAP Readiness Check analysis:

  • Type of planning used (Building Block / Campaign / Bottleneck / pull capacity planning / Trimming)
  • Used statistical models for demand generation
  • Used heuristic planning profiles
  • Used planning areas for each module
  • Planning strategy used, including customized configuration
  • Global configuration information referred to module GATP (Global-Available-to-Promise)
  • Distribution configuration information
  • Layout of the delivery network
  • Customized key figures and attributes in the system
  • Feature-based prediction settings
  • Number of documents managed in APO

 

Getting Started
To set up and run SAP Readiness Check for SAP Supply Chain solutions, the subsequent steps need to be performed:
Follow the instructions in SAP Note 3477050 - SAP Readiness Check for SAP Supply Chain solutions to install the check framework and transport the changes into your target system, such as the productive client of the production system. The note provides detailed and technical information on how to set up and perform the analysis.

Initiate program RC_SCM_COLLECT_ANALYSIS_DATA via transaction SA38 or SE38 to initialize the data collectors.

Select the scope of the analysis by activating or deactivating the corresponding checkboxes. Use the Schedule Analysis button to schedule the data collection. The process runs as a background job to avoid timeout issues.

The runtime of the data collectors depends on many factors, like server capacity, data volumes, and component usage. Therefore, it is difficult to predict the runtime. The data collection process was intentionally designed to avoid contention or interference with production workloads; consequently, you may see longer than expected runtimes. The best way to forecast the runtime for a production system is to conduct the data collection process in a copy of production using a similar hardware configuration.

Once the analysis has finished, you can download the results to your local filesystem using the Download Analysis Data button. The generated data collection archive is a ZIP file containing multiple XML files. All collected data is human-readable and can be easily inspected with appropriate XML viewers.

Launch the SAP Readiness Check cloud application on SAP for Me or from within your SAP Cloud ALM tenant and choose Start New Analysis to upload the ZIP archive. After a few seconds, the results of the newly created SAP Readiness Check analysis can be explored.

As always, we look forward to receiving your feedback!
Your SAP Readiness Check Team

entry.title: Enhanced Organizational Structure Profile in SAP Readiness Check for SAP ERP Usage & Data Profiling
entry.content:
Organizations planning a transition to SAP S/4HANA require comprehensive tools that offer insights into their existing SAP ERP Central Component (SAP ECC) systems. The Organizational Structure Profile within SAP Readiness Check for SAP ERP Usage and Data Profiling serves this purpose. Today, we proudly announce the availability of the new version of the Organizational Structure Profile as part of SAP Readiness Check for SAP ERP Usage and Data Profiling. We deliver significantly enhanced analysis features in this latest version, providing better clarity, deeper analytical capabilities, and a more user-friendly interface.

Figure 1: Updated Version of the Organizational Structure Profile

 

Understanding the Business Context

The Organizational Structure Profile provides a holistic overview of an organization's SAP ECC 6.0 system structure. This profile is essential for understanding the relationships between various organizational units and identifying opportunities for optimization before transitioning to SAP S/4HANA. The Organizational Structure Profile automates a previously manual and resource-intensive process, enabling organizations to reduce the time and cost associated with scoping and assessing organizational objects.

The enhancements in this new version address several shortcomings of the previous version, including:

  • Limited scope: The previous version lacked coverage for certain organizational items (e.., controlling areas, storage locations, distribution channels, etc.), preventing a comprehensive analysis.
  • Lack of relationship data: The absence of explicit relationship data hindered a complete understanding of organizational dynamics.
  • Simplistic user interface: Users were unable to efficiently access and interact with detailed and interconnected information due to a flat and feature-limited user interface.

The latest version addresses these shortcomings, transforming the Organizational Structure Profile into a more robust and insightful tool.

Key Capabilities of the Enhanced Organizational Structure Profile

Expanded Scope and Coverage of Organizational Item Types

The updated version significantly broadens its scope by including additional organizational item types essential for a comprehensive understanding of the organizational structure. These include:

  • Controlling Areas
  • Cost Centers
  • Profit Centers
  • Company Codes
  • Plants
  • Shipping Points
  • Storage Locations
  • Purchasing Organizations
  • Sales Organizations
  • Distribution Channels
  • Divisions

This expanded coverage gives organizations a holistic view of their structure, ensuring that all relevant organizational elements are considered and more thoroughly examined during the transition. This insight allows project teams to make informed decisions during the transition planning phase.

Enhanced Visualization of Organizational Relationships

This new version offers improved visualization capabilities to clarify the complex relationships between organizational items. These include:

  • Hierarchical network graphs: Graphical representations display parent (ancestor) and child relationships, clearly visualizing organizational hierarchies.
  • Color-coded structures: Different organizational types are represented with distinct colors, improving the clarity and usability of network visualizations.
  • Expandable/collapsible elements: Network components can expand and collapse, allowing users to focus on specific areas of interest within the organizational structure.

Figure 2: The Parent Object and Child Object Network Graphs of a Sales Organization Item

 

These advanced visualization capabilities facilitate a more intuitive understanding of organizational structures and interdependencies, empowering project teams to make well-informed decisions during transition planning.

Detailed Usage Analysis for Making Informed Decisions

The enhancements include incorporating detailed usage analysis to help organizations quickly identify actively used organizational items and those that may be obsolete. Historically, determining whether an organizational unit is actively contributing to business processes or is no longer relevant is time-consuming. This new version now simplifies this process with advanced usage indicators, enabling teams to streamline assessments, accelerate decision-making based on usage data, and optimize resources by eliminating obsolete elements.

To evaluate the usage status of an organizational item, related business objects for all organizational item types in scope were identified and are used to analyze their data volumes and activities regarding the selected organization. The resulting data for these business objects are presented in the "Usage Indicator" card of the detail view (see figure 3). Each business object is assigned a usage status, categorized as "Active," "Likely Not Active," or "Not Active":

  • Active (Green): Indicates that the business object is currently actively used for the organizational item in focus, having a data volume higher than 20 items and recent activity over the last three years.
  • Likely Not Active (Yellow): States that the usage status of this business object is uncertain about the selected organizational item, with limited data volumes or lack of recent activity, warranting further investigation.
  • Not Active (Red): Confirms that the business object is not being used for the selected organizational item, with a data volume less than 20 items and no recent activity over the last three years.

Based on the usage indicators of the related business objects, the usage status of the selected organizational item is determined and presented in the header of the detail view (see figure 3):

  • Active (Green): The organizational item is currently actively used. It has at least one related business object which is actively used.
  • Likely Not Active (Yellow): The usage status of the selected organizational item is ambiguous, demanding further investigation. No related business object is actively used, but there are objects with usage status "Likely Not Active" and/or "Not Active."
  • Not Active (Red): The organizational item is not being used. All related business objects have the usage indicator value "Not Active."

For a more detailed understanding of calculating usage indicators, click on the 'Learn More' button to access the Organizational Structure Profile help panel.

Figure 3: Detail View of a Plant Organizational Item, Including Usage Indicators Card and Open Help Panel

 

We strongly recommend that the project team, particularly the business owners of the involved organizational units, conduct further investigations to validate and confirm the findings from the usage data analysis. This additional validation ensures the accuracy and reliability of the insights, facilitating more informed decision-making.

Identification of Orphaned Organizational Items

The enhanced version automatically identifies, and flags orphaned organizational items that lack proper parent-child hierarchy links, signaling potential structural inefficiencies or errors. By highlighting these gaps, the Organizational Structure Profile enables organizations to address structural inconsistencies proactively, minimize transition risks, and ensure the integrity and completeness of their organizational model throughout the transition process.

Figure 4: A Plant Without a Corresponding Company Code is Marked as an Orphaned Item

 

 

Redesigned User Interface for Enhanced Usability

To address usability concerns, the enhanced Organizational Structure Profile features a completely redesigned user interface that significantly improves usability:

  • Flexible column layout: The interface is divided into two main sections - a list of organizational items on the left and detailed information about the selected item on the right.
  • Intuitive filtering: Users can filter organizational items by type through a view selector or search for specific items using a text-based search field.
  • Detailed information sections: The detail view includes:
    • Master data information
    • Usage indicators showing the status of related business objects
    • Dependent data sections displaying related organizational items
    • Network graphs visualizing parent and child hierarchies
  • Export capabilities: Users can export both the list of organizational items and detailed information about specific items for further analysis or reporting.
  • Related data access: Links to related data collectors enable users to access additional information relevant to the selected organizational item type.

Figure 5: Detail View of a Company Code Organizational Item and Available Filter Options

 

This newly designed user interface makes it easier for project teams to navigate and analyze complex organizational structures without requiring specialized knowledge.

Cross-Profile Integration

The enhanced Organizational Structure Profile integrates seamlessly with other profiles within the SAP Readiness Check for SAP ERP Usage and Data Profiling:

  • Usage indicators are linked to the Initial Data Migration Profile, allowing users to navigate directly to detailed information about related business objects. This integration provides a more holistic view of the system landscape and facilitates comprehensive analysis.
  • Hyperlinks to related data collectors enable users to access additional information and gain a more comprehensive understanding of their system landscape.

Figure 6: A Company Code Organizational Item and its Collection of Links to Related Data Collectors

Use Cases

Transitioning to SAP S/4HANA can be more than just a data migration exercise - it could be a strategic opportunity to optimize business structures and eliminate inefficiencies. The enhanced Organizational Structure Profile is a powerful tool that offers valuable insights regardless of the transition scenario.

Selective Data Transition Planning

Understanding the organizational structure and usage patterns is crucial for projects involving selective data transition. The new version helps identify actively used organizational elements, highlighting those that should be migrated versus those that can be discarded, optimizing the transition process.

Organizational Structure Optimization

Many organizations use the transition to SAP S/4HANA as an opportunity to streamline their organizational structure. The enhanced analysis provides the insight needed to identify redundant or unused organizational elements, supporting informed decision-making during this optimization process.

Transition Sequence Planning

Understanding dependencies between organizational items is essential for planning the transition sequence. The network visualization capabilities of the Organizational Structure Profile make these dependencies clear, helping project teams develop more effective transition strategies.

Data Quality Assessment

Orphaned item detection and usage analysis contribute to an overall data quality assessment. This evaluation enables organizations to address inconsistencies and ensure that only relevant, high-quality data migrates to the new system.

Next Steps for Users

Follow these steps to take advantage of the new Organizational Structure Profile:

  1. System preparation and data collection: Implement the latest version of SAP Note 3112362 and run an SAP Readiness Check for SAP ERP Usage and Data Profiling analysis by following the instructions described within the SAP Note, including uploading the data collection archive to the SAP Readiness Check cloud application.
  2. Explore the analysis results: Identify organizational items of interest and examine their usage and dependent data.
  3. Visualize hierarchical relationships: Use the network graphs to understand the relationships between specific organizational items.
  4. Filter and search: Use the filtering and search capabilities to focus on specific segments of the organizational structure.
  5. Identify optimization opportunities: Review usage status indicators to identify potentially unused or redundant organizational items.
  6. Investigate orphaned items: Address organizational items with disrupted hierarchy paths to ensure structural consistency.
  7. Explore related data: Use the links to associated data collectors to gain additional insights about specific organizational item types.
  8. Export for collaboration: Export relevant data for sharing with stakeholders and for further analysis.

As an alternative to creating a new analysis in the SAP Readiness Check cloud application, you can update your existing SAP Readiness Check for SAP ERP Usage and Data Profiling analysis. Start by implementing the latest version of SAP Note 3112362 and rerun the data collection process in your SAP ECC system. Then, using the newly created data collection archive, update the existing analysis data using the Update Analysis option within the header of the dashboard view in the SAP Readiness Check cloud application on SAP for Me or your SAP Cloud ALM tenant.

 As always, we look forward to receiving your feedback.

SAP Readiness Check team

entry.title: New SAP Readiness Check Landing Page in SAP for Me
entry.content:
Dear all,

SAP Readiness Check has evolved over the last years to become a vital planning tool for the most critical SAP transformation journeys. Currently, SAP Readiness Check includes support for nine scenarios and has processed over 85,000 analyses since its inception in 2019.

With our continuously growing number of SAP Readiness Check scenarios, we felt it was time to revamp the SAP Readiness Check cloud application landing page. We are happy to provide you with a restructured landing page in SAP for Me and SAP Cloud ALM, offering easy navigation and orientation at first glance, and being the one-stop shop for all things related to SAP Readiness Check.

The Getting Started section contains the How to Start link, which opens a guided procedure explaining the steps to create a new SAP Readiness Check analysis.

Familiarize yourself with the steps to prepare for creating your first SAP Readiness Check analysis.

The Supported Scenarios section contains links to the central guidance note for each SAP Readiness Check scenario. Each SAP Note lists the requirements to implement and run the SAP Readiness Check data collectors for the specific scenario in your system. Please read the respective SAP Note carefully before scheduling the data collection job; it contains essential hints to avoid long-running data collection jobs and other valuable information.

After the data collection jobs finish, you can create a new analysis by uploading the generated data archive to the SAP Readiness Check landing page. To do so, click Create New Analysis in the top right corner of the Analyses section.

Enter a name for the analysis, verify your customer information, and select the results archive from your local filesystem. Accept the Terms of Use and decide if you want to authorize SAP employees access to your results.

Note: With the Authorization checkbox, you grant SAP employees access to your SAP Readiness Check results. Alternatively, you can grant individual access to specific e-mail addresses later within the analysis dashboard.

Clicking Create, the application immediately processes the provided data collection archive file and produces a new analysis, accessible as an interactive dashboard. You can select the analysis from the list and start reviewing the results.

The list of analyses can be expanded by selecting the Show All button in the Analyses section, which will display all analyses your user is authorized to access. Within the analysis list, you may search for an analysis or use the filter options to limit the view to a specific scenario or analysis status. In addition, you can create a list of favorite analyses.

 New feature: Combined Scenarios

Released with the new SAP Readiness Check cloud application landing page, you can now combine analyses of different scenarios for the same system and client.

For instance, you can now update an existing SAP Readiness Check for SAP S/4HANA analysis with the data collection archive produced by SAP Readiness Check for SAP ERP Usage and Data Profiling and/or SAP Readiness Check for SAP SuccessFactors Solutions for the same system and client. Similarly, you can update an SAP Readiness Check for SAP S/4HANA Upgrades analysis with the data collection archive produced by SAP Readiness Check for SAP SuccessFactors Solutions.

To combine analyses, use the Update Analysis button within an existing SAP Readiness Check for SAP S/4HANA or SAP Readiness Check for SAP S/4HANA Upgrades analysis to add the additional scenario. The resulting combined analysis includes a tab for each scenario within the dashboard header.

 

The What’s New section of the SAP Readiness Check landing page always shows the latest blogs from the SAP Readiness Check Community to keep you up-to-date on new scenarios, features, and enhancements.

The Additional Information section provides links to the SAP Help Portal, SAP Community, learning areas, SAP Activate, related topics, and recommended training material.

We hope you enjoy the new look and feel!

entry.title: How to prepare the system for SAP S/4HANA upgrades - SAP Readiness Check
entry.content:
If you're planning an upgrade to SAP S/4HANA, the SAP Readiness Check is a valuable tool to help you assess your system's current state and identify any potential issues before the upgrade.

An accurate Readiness Check analysis starts with collecting important system information—such as usage statistics, custom code analysis, and configuration details.

This information is gathered using data collectors, which are ABAP-based tools that extract relevant data from your SAP system.

To set up the data collectors, refer to the SAP Notes outlined in the section below for step-by-step instructions.

Step 1: System preparation

Before implementing the required SAP Notes for the data collectors, make sure the following Notes are already applied in their latest versions:

  • SAP Note 1668882 – Note Assistant: Important notes for SAP_BASIS 730,731,740,750,751,752,753,754,755,756,757,758
  • SAP Note 2971435 – SNOTE – Delta calculation issue when 'mod unit' positions are changed

These Notes help ensure your system is up to date and minimize the risk of errors during setup.

To make the implementation process easier, you can use the Note Analyzer tool available in the Note Assistant. For instructions and the input file, refer to SAP Note 3365856 – Note Analyzer Input File for SAP Readiness Check for SAP S/4HANA upgrades.

2758146SAP Readiness Check FrameworkSV-SCS-S4RRC_COLLECT_ANALYSIS_DATA

If SAP Note 2310438 has been implemented previously, it must be reverted prior to implementing SAP Note 2758146.

2399707Simplification Item Relevance & Compatibility ScopeCA-TRS-PRCKTMW_RC_SITEM_DATA_COLL

Enables simplification item relevance, compatibility scope analysis, and target S/4HANA version selection in RC_COLLECT_ANALYSIS_DATA. Implementation is mandatory. SAP Note 2502552 and the consistency check from this note are optional but recommended.

2903677Effort Drivers for Simplification ItemsCA-TRS-PRCKTMW_RC_EFD_DATA_COLL

This SAP Note offers the ability to include the effort driver analysis for simplification items with the initial effort ranking of Potentially High. The result is that effort ranking for some simplification items could be recalculated based on the scope and complexity of the system being analyzed.

2502552Consistency Check for Simplification ItemsCA-TRS-PRCKTMW_RC_SITEM_DATA_COLL

This SAP Note enables the optional data collection process for the consistency check. If you opt to include this data in your analysis, please ensure that you always use the latest version of this SAP Note. It is an addition to SAP Note 2399707. You must read and implement SAP Note 2399707 first and follow all steps, including the implementation of related SAP Notes listed in SAP Note 2399707.

3061414Integration AnalysisSV-SMG-MON-BPM-DCM–

This SAP Note details the steps required to enable successful execution of the Integration check data collectors. The check results provide insight into interfaces that could be impacted as part of an SAP S/4HANA upgrade project and provides guidance on mitigating the impact.

Please note that the data collector for this extended analysis is delivered starting with version 56 of SAP Note 2758146. SAP Note 3061414 only outlines the steps necessary for successful execution of the check, including required prerequisite SAP Notes.

2827612Innovation Potential DashboardSV-SCS-S4RTMW_RC_INNOVA_DATA_COLL

This SAP Note is responsible for enabling the optional Innovation Potential analysis, which populates the Innovation Potential dashboard with guidance on possible areas for future innovation based on current system usage statistics.

If the ST-PI component version in the landscape is less than or equal to ST-PI 2008_1_700 SP27, ST-PI 2008_1_710 SP27, or ST-PI 740 SP17, you need to implement the SAP Note 2827612 to enable innovation potential sub check.

2781766Custom Code Analysis via ATCBC-DWB-CEX–

Requires ATC setup and variant S4HANA_READINESS. See SAP Notes 2436688 and 3293011.

Step 2: Necessary authorizations

The user who is used to schedule the data collectors must have the following authorization:

  • Authorization object S_PROGRAM with values P_GROUP = RC_COLL and P_ACTION = SUBMIT, BTCSUBMIT, VARIANT.

The user ID used for scheduling the data collector for Custom Code Analysis must have the following authorizations:

  • Authorization object S_Q_ADM with values ACTVT = Add or Create (01), Change (02), Execute (16) and ATC_OBJTYP = Check run (01), Configuration (04)
  • Authorization object S_Q_GOVERN with values ACTVT = Delete (06), Confirm (31) and ATC_OTYPGO = Exemption (01)

Step 3: Data Collection

  1. Launch the SAP Readiness Check data collection report (RC_COLLECT_ANALYSIS_DATA).
  2. Choose Schedule Analysis to schedule the master job to collect data.
  3. Select the Download Analysis Data option in the data collection report once the collection process completes.
  • Optional: Review the data collected in the compressed file.
  • Optional: Alter the data collected as required to address any potential data protection concerns and then repackage the contents.
  • Optional: Check the XML file content via the browser.

Step 4: Custom Code Analysis (Recommended)

Via the SAP Readiness Check data collection report (RC_COLLECT_ANALYSIS_DATA) in a non-productive system

  1. Launch the SAP Readiness Check data collection report (RC_COLLECT_ANALYSIS_DATA).
  2. Choose the target release, select the Custom Code Analysis check, and deselect any other checks.
  3. Choose Schedule Analysis to schedule the master job to collect data.
  4. Select the Download Analysis Data option in the data collection report once the collection process completes.
  5. Choose Update Analysis at the top of the dashboard view to add the ABAP test cockpit export to the SAP Readiness Check analysis.

Note: The custom code analysis results of a non-production system can be uploaded to an existing SAP Readiness Check analysis created for a production system.

Manually via the ABAP Test Cockpit

  1. Schedule an ABAP test cockpit run using the S4HANA_READINESS variant for the current product version (to create a baseline).
  2. Using the results from the previous step, maintain the baseline to exempt the findings. You can do this within the Manage Results screen in the ABAP Test Cockpit by selecting the relevant results and following the dropdown menu option: Maintain Baseline -> Add Selected Results To -> Exempt Findings.
  3. Schedule a second ABAP test cockpit run using the S4HANA_READINESS variant for the selected target release, ensuring the Consider Baseline setting is enabled.
  4. Export the results of the second ABAP test cockpit run by selecting the context menu option Export to -> File for SAP Readiness Check in the ABAP test cockpit result browser.
  5. Choose Update Analysis at the top of the dashboard view to add the ABAP test cockpit export to the SAP Readiness Check analysis.

Additional information:

To learn more about how to use SAP Readiness Check for S/4HANA upgrades, please refer to SAP Note 3059197 - SAP Readiness Check for SAP S/4HANA upgrades.

entry.title: Modernize with SAP Business Data Cloud using the SAP Business Data Cloud Modernization Assessment
entry.content:
SAP Business Data Cloud is the evolution of SAP data and analytics solutions and embodies the path forward for SAP Business Warehouse customers.

Start exploring the modernization journey with the brochure
“How to modernize SAP Business Warehouse with SAP Business Data Cloud.”

Since organizations are in different stages of their cloud modernization journey, SAP supports customers with the expert-guided SAP Business Data Cloud modernization assessment, analyzing your currently used SAP on-premises data and analytics solutions and helping to find your specific path to cloud modernization with SAP Business Data Cloud.

The SAP Business Data Cloud modernization assessment is a complimentary, limited-time readout that provides deep insights into your SAP Business Warehouse, SAP BusinessObjects, and SAP HANA environments. Based on usage, discover which investments are most active, identify areas that can be modernized, and receive best practices for an actionable modernization plan for SAP Business Data Cloud.

With the results from this readout, you can:

  • Understand the usage patterns of your SAP Business Warehouse, SAP BusinessObjects, or SAP HANA environments to help with modernization prioritization.
  • Explore modernization options to begin your SAP Business Data Cloud journey.
  • Define a data strategy with scalable cloud solutions that prepares you for the era of AI.

Apply here for your free SAP Business Data Cloud modernization assessment!
